commit_message:
doc: add version discovery guideline in api concept doc

This patch adds basic guideline how to discover microversion with
version API.

blueprint complete-todo-in-api-concept-doc

Change-Id: I55b50e8300c67b9ec94587a2bdccac55a9c115a0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/44/264044/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - **Legacy v2 API user with new cloud** The minimum version of Microversions is `2.1`, which is a version compatible with the legacy v2 API. The legacy v2 API user doesn't need to worry that their older client software will be broken when their cloud is upgraded with new versions. And the cloud operator doesn't need to worry that upgrading their cloud to newer versions will break any user with older clients that don't expect these changes. - **User old client with new cloud** Before using the old client to talk to new cloud, the old client can check the minimum version of microversions to ensure whether the cloud is compatible with the old API. This avoids the old client to be broken accidentally. Besides, the operator also can use minimum version to ensure old client can still work with upgraded cloud. - **User enables new features** The new features can be discovered by microversions. User client should check the microversions firstly, and new features are only enabled when clouds support. With this way, the user client can work with old and new clouds simultaneously. - **User discovers the difference between clouds** User client needs talk to mulitple different version clouds. User client can discover different API features through the microverisions. Version Discovery ================= The Version API will return the minimum and maximum versions. These values are used by the client to discovery the API supported version. Request to '/' will get version info for all endpoints. A response would look as follows :: { "versions": [ { "id": "v2.0", "links": [ { "href": "http://openstack.example.com/v2/", "rel": "self" } ], "status": "SUPPORTED", "version": "", "min_version": "", "updated": "2011-01-21T11:33:21Z" }, { "id": "v2.1", "links": [ { "href": "http://openstack.example.com/v2.1/", "rel": "self" } ], "status": "CURRENT", "version": "2.14", "min_version": "2.1", "updated": "2013-07-23T11:33:21Z" } ] } "version" is maximum version, "min_version" is minimum version. If the value is empty string, it means this endpoint doesn't support microversions. It is legacy v2 API endpoint. As the endpoint `http://openstack.example.com/v2/` in the above sample. The endpoint `http://openstack.example.com/v2.1/` support microversions, and the maximum version is `2.14`, the minimum version is `2.1`. The client should use one of valid versions to access endpoint. You can also obtain specific endpoint version info by performing a GET the base version URL(such as, `http://openstack.example.com/v2.1/`). You can get more info about version API at :doc:`versions`

The legacy v2 API user doesn't need to worry that their older client software will be broken when their cloud is upgraded with new versions. And the cloud operator doesn't need to worry that upgrading their cloud to newer versions will break any user with older clients that don't expect these changes. User old client with new cloud ============================== Before using the old client to talk to new cloud, the old client can check the minimum version of microversions to ensure whether the cloud is compatible with the old API. This avoids the old client to be broken accidentally. Besides, the operator also can use minimum version to ensure old client can still work with upgraded cloud. User enables new features ========================= The new features can be discovered by microversions. User client should check the microversions firstly, and new features are only enabled when clouds support. With this way, the user client can work with old and new clouds simultaneously. User discovers the difference between clouds =========================================== User client needs talk to mulitple different version clouds. User client can discover different API features through the microverisions.

commit_message:
Versioned objects support for ResourceClass

Version 1.0 of a simple ResourceClass object which is persistable in
the api database. A single object has an id and a name and created_at
and updated_at timestamps.

The unit tests are fairly contrived (too much work in the mocks)
so functional tests are also provided.

Change-Id: If9ed892f23a59218c7970fcb745b624007c43a38
Partially-Implements: blueprint resource-classes

commit_message:
Allow sourcing apt_key from ansible host or URL

This change allows deployers to specify locally sourced apt keys
on the ansible host or URL rather than requiring all apt keys to
be downloaded from upstream keyservers.

The current implementation requires that all containers and hosts
we deploy to have an internet connection to download apt keys for
the various repos. This change allows the user to source apt keys
from the deployment host like for example:

galera_client_gpg_keys:
  - key_name: 'mariadb'
    data: "{{ lookup('file', '/etc/openstack_deploy/keys/mariadb.gpg') }}"
    hash_id: '0xcbcb082a1bb943db'
  - key_name: 'percona-xtrabackup'
    keyserver: 'hkp://keyserver.ubuntu.com:80'
    fallback_keyserver: 'hkp://p80.pool.sks-keyservers.net:80'
    hash_id: '0x1c4cbdcdcd2efd2a'

Note: Deployers can already set the repo URLs to use local sources,
so this enables fully offline package installation.

Change-Id: I14a661fe018077e5bff579a61fe83324bc996e6a

commit_message:
Fix a call to retry_command function

This patch fixes a call to the function retry_command.
By some reasons we forgot to add a named argument 'command'
and in some cases function fails with error:
TypeError: argument of type 'NoneType' is not iterable

Change-Id: I4c0dd7f480bb1536af0d657b2221a43e2ae03c95
Closes-Bug:1538045
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-ostf refs/changes/36/272436/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: return self.retry_command(retries=retries[0], timeout=retries[1], method=ssh.exec_command, command=cmd)

commit_message:
Add Fuel Master host entry to /etc/hosts during install

RabbitMQ will fail to start if it cannot resolve the hostname
for itself, so this will cover the case where a user skips
fuelmenu.

Change-Id: I9a08716b03d3c3aa3b1c87592172d29b062502e2
Related-Bug: #1538509

added_lines: from ceilometer.objects import alarm as object_alarmdef is_over_quota(project_id, user_id): user_alarms = object_alarm.Alarm.get_all(user=user_id) project_alarms = object_alarm.Alarm.get_all(project=project_id) alarms = object_alarm.Alarm.get_all(alarm_id=self._id, project=auth_project) object_alarm.AlarmChange.create(payload) alarms = object_alarm.Alarm.get_all( name=data.name, project=data.project_id) alarm = object_alarm.Alarm.update(alarm_in) object_alarm.Alarm.delete(alarm.alarm_id) q, pecan.request.alarm_storage_conn.get_alarm_changes, ['on_behalf_of', 'alarm_id']) alarm_changes = object_alarm.AlarmChange.get_all( self._id, auth_project, **kwargs) return [AlarmChange.from_db_model(ac) for ac in alarm_changes] alarm = object_alarm.Alarm.update(alarm) def _record_creation(data, alarm_id, now): object_alarm.AlarmChange.create(payload) if is_over_quota(data.project_id, data.user_id): alarms = object_alarm.Alarm.get_all(name=data.name, project=data.project_id) alarm = object_alarm.Alarm.create(alarm_in) self._record_creation(change, alarm.alarm_id, now) alarms = object_alarm.Alarm.get_all(**kwargs) return [Alarm.from_db_model(a) for a in alarms]
deleted_lines: def is_over_quota(conn, project_id, user_id): :param conn: a backend connection object user_alarms = list(conn.get_alarms(user=user_id)) project_alarms = list(conn.get_alarms(project=project_id)) self.conn = pecan.request.alarm_storage_conn alarms = list(self.conn.get_alarms(alarm_id=self._id, project=auth_project)) self.conn.record_alarm_change(payload) alarms = list(self.conn.get_alarms(name=data.name, project=data.project_id)) alarm = self.conn.update_alarm(alarm_in) self.conn.delete_alarm(alarm.alarm_id) conn = pecan.request.alarm_storage_conn q, conn.get_alarm_changes, ['on_behalf_of', 'alarm_id']) return [AlarmChange.from_db_model(ac) for ac in conn.get_alarm_changes(self._id, auth_project, **kwargs)] alarm = self.conn.update_alarm(alarm) def _record_creation(conn, data, alarm_id, now): conn.record_alarm_change(payload) conn = pecan.request.alarm_storage_conn if is_over_quota(conn, data.project_id, data.user_id): alarms = list(conn.get_alarms(name=data.name, project=data.project_id)) alarm = conn.create_alarm(alarm_in) self._record_creation(conn, change, alarm.alarm_id, now) return [Alarm.from_db_model(m) for m in pecan.request.alarm_storage_conn.get_alarms(**kwargs)]

commit_message:
Versioned object initial patch

Versioned objects provide a layer of abstraction on SQLAlchemy objects,
allowing for database schema independence. As a result, upgrade compatibility
across distributed services will be possible.

Implementation of oslo.versionedobjects. This commit consists basic
mechanism for oslo.versionedobjects. It should be base for
implementation versioning to other objects.

Partially Implements: blueprint versioned-objects

Change-Id: I49463dfb40c2539f8ecc97e10b05823bdeb270c7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer refs/changes/75/178675/25 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from ceilometer.objects import sample as object_sample samples = object_sample.Sample.get_all(f, limit=limit) return samples samples = object_sample.Sample.get_all(f) if not samples: return samples[0]
deleted_lines: return map(Sample.from_db_model, pecan.request.storage_conn.get_samples(f, limit=limit)) samples = list(pecan.request.storage_conn.get_samples(f)) if len(samples) < 1: return Sample.from_db_model(samples[0])

commit_message:
adding project config for openstack-salt-formulas.

The openstack-salt team is beginning work on providing
Salt forumlas for Openstack, and a git repo is necessary
to host our code.

Change-Id: Ic03ba1e5a87e1eb346ea323c8b918f22f961fd51

); })}

Fix the UI bug on Compute pane with the 'next' button

Restrictions are processed before render, so next button state is fixed

commit_message:
testtools was moved to main requirements file

Since now murano engine doesn't start without
testools package it should be in requirements.txt
file rather than optional test-requirements.txt

Change-Id: Ia2669b0d229378ef6c17c7976ade16b3e94105be

commit_message:
ceph, swift: do not fail if unprocess measures already deleted

If several workers are trying to delete the same unprocessed metric at
the same time, they might fail to do so. Ignore these error, as it's not
a big deal in the end: they're deleted.

Closes-Bug: #1537767
Change-Id: Ib8002b757698a8c6601bc63614cc0c63a18f2e83
(cherry picked from commit 115c275a667bf60c694d02f12800de52c857593e)

commit_message:
Disable xattrs in IPA extraction

The CoreOS IPA image appears to be failing upon extraction
of the IPA container due to a failure to applicaiton of xattr
values.  Manually testing with-in the CoreOS image reveals
that adding --no-attrs to the command line allows tar to
complete successfully.

Change-Id: I9b2bf6ff47822bc46259e2bbb27bd575889786a3
Closes-Bug: #1538310

commit_message:
Fix xtremio slow unit tests

This commit mocks out time.sleep() in the test_retry_request()
method of test_emc_xtremio.EMCXIODriverTestCase.

As documented in the accompanying bug, this yields about a 6X
speedup for this unit test suite.

Change-Id: I86647dce1fe8a6e8281ee3617fbc5e5c1332404d
Closes-Bug: #1536782
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/36/271036/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import time @mock.patch.object(time, 'sleep', mock.Mock(return_value=0))

commit_message:
Only consider requested_destination

When an admin requests a live-migrate or evacuate, they can specify a
host. Record that on the RequestSpec so that when we select_destinations
we can only consider the requested host.

requested_destination is not set yet, see future patches.

Blueprint check-destination-on-migrations

Change-Id: Ie4ab4e8d63a2a987bb045aba05d006dfeb12187e

uefi: add uefi boot support

This patch add the section about how to launch instances from UEFI
images.

Change-Id: I03812c50eba54d5c42e91ebf29079aa1af9d728a
Implements: blueprint boot-from-uefi
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/78/270678/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Launch instances with UEFI ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ UEFI (Unified Extensible Firmware Interface) is a standard firmware designed to replace legacy BIOS. There is a slow but steady trend for OSes to move to the UEFI format and in some cases to make the UEFI format their only format. **To configure uefi environment** In order that an instance can be launched successfully from an UEFI image in QEMU/KVM environment, the cloud administrator have to install the following packages in compute node: ``OVMF from EDK2`` OVMF is a port of Intel's tianocore firmware to qemu virtual machine, in other words this project enables UEFI support for Virtual Machines. ``libvirt >= 1.2.9`` Libvirt has been supporting UEFI boot since version 1.2.9. Because default UEFI loader path is `/usr/share/OVMF/OVMF_CODE.fd`, the cloud administrator must create one link to this location after UEFI package is installed. **To upload UEFI images** To launch instances from an UEFI image, the administrative users have to firstly upload one UEFI image. To do so, `hw_firmware_type` property must be set to `uefi` when the image is created. For example:: glance image-create --container-format bare --disk-format qcow2 \ --property hw_firmware_type=uefi --file /tmp/cloud-uefi.qcow --name uefi After that, you can launch instances from this UEFI image.

commit_message:
controller: make sure heat use 'rabbit' rpc_backend

A recent patch in puppet-heat [1] changed the default value for
rpc_backend.
It was 'rabbit' and is now $::os_service_default which means it will
take the value in OpenStack.

To keep backward compatibility, this patch will make sure we'll
use this value set in Hiera.

[1] Iff0275b701f2096f6f927ff962ef06c673827b4e

Change-Id: If0a9ed4baaf5be821bb29c7e373791e2e6cc6003
Partial-Bug: #1538127

commit_message:
puppet-stack-config: make sure heat use 'rabbit' rpc_backend

A recent patch in puppet-heat [1] changed the default value for
rpc_backend.
It was 'rabbit' and is now $::os_service_default which means it will
take the value in OpenStack.

To keep backward compatibility, this patch will make sure we'll still
use this value set in Hiera.

[1] Iff0275b701f2096f6f927ff962ef06c673827b4e

Partial-Bug: #1538127
Change-Id: Idceeb178575bbe095c4d03f04b45fc50902f52f4

commit_message:
Fix es translations

There's a problem in the Spanish translations where they are invalid
and cannot get compiled.

We're not syncing with translation server anymore, so update the strings
manually and fix them.

To verify run
find nova -type f -regex '.*\.pot?' -print0| xargs -0 -n 1 msgfmt \
--check-format -o /dev/null

Before this change:
nova/locale/es/LC_MESSAGES/nova.po:5557: 'msgstr' is not a valid Python
format string, unlike 'msgid'. Reason: The string ends in the middle of
a directive.
nova/locale/es/LC_MESSAGES/nova.po:5567: 'msgstr' is not a valid Python
format string, unlike 'msgid'. Reason: The string ends in the middle of
a directive.
msgfmt: found 2 fatal errors
nova/locale/es/LC_MESSAGES/nova-log-error.po:1366: a format
specification for argument 'args' doesn't exist in 'msgstr'
msgfmt: found 1 fatal error

Now this works fine.

Closes-Bug: #1536214
Change-Id: I4717ecce0f640ffa9538a54a3e7fce85795d2515

commit_message:
Re-enable and improve VPNaaS tests

There were VPNaaS tests that were disabled because of an upstream bug.
It's already solved so re-enable them again. Besides, this patch makes
the vpn service and ipsec site connection update tests more specific
to avoid regressions, as we also check that the dtos sent to the midonet
backend actually contain the fields updated.

Change-Id: I771730f6f356c55bf16935548b3fc107d8f38cad
Signed-off-by: Xavi Len <xavi.leon@midokura.com>

commit_message:
Treat match-by of null as []

The API sometimes sends null for match-by when it should send []. Make the
Threshold Engine more tolerant by treating null as []

Change-Id: Idf29e58c27a2c0ba531d041a144e8c5f35b6be46
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/monasca-thresh refs/changes/15/272315/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import java.util.ArrayList; final List<String> newMatchBy; if (event.matchBy == null) { // The API can send NULL which means empty list newMatchBy = new ArrayList<>(0); } else { newMatchBy = event.matchBy; } if (!alarmDefinition.getMatchBy().equals(newMatchBy)) { logger.error("AlarmDefinition {}: match-by Er, was {} now {}", event.alarmDefinitionId, alarmDefinition.getMatchBy(), newMatchBy); } alarmDefinition.setMatchBy(newMatchBy); // Should never change
deleted_lines: if (!alarmDefinition.getMatchBy().equals(event.matchBy)) { logger.error("AlarmDefinition {}: match-by changed, was {} now {}", event.alarmDefinitionId, alarmDefinition.getMatchBy(), event.matchBy); } alarmDefinition.setMatchBy(event.matchBy); // Should never change

commit_message:
Fix sluggish rbd unit tests

The rbd_test.py module tests methods decorated by utils.retry,
which does retries with exponential backoffs, without mocking out
time.sleep().

This commit mocks time.sleep(), yielding a 3x speedup, as documented
in the accompanying bug.

Closes-Bug: #1536717

Change-Id: I414629f09f397e44d3a5be794ef83658a4c1eec0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/25/270925/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Turn [...] and {...} into regular operators

[] and {} operators were put into standard operators
table so that it will not have fixed precedence anymore.
These operators have special handling in the parser,
but now it is possible to insert operators with precedence
higher than the dot operator without breaking the grammar.

Change-Id: I9dd13608a5eba6ff8caf3418a81ef96572289c2b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/yaql refs/changes/69/272969/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Turn [...] and {...} into regular operators

[] and {} operators were put into standard operators
table so that it will not have fixed precedence anymore.
These operators have special handling in the parser,
but now it is possible to insert operators with precedence
higher than the dot operator without breaking the grammar.

Change-Id: I9dd13608a5eba6ff8caf3418a81ef96572289c2b

added_lines: self.data = "abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz" def stat(self): return {'size': len(self.data)} def read(self, offset, length): limit = offset + length return self.data[offset:limit] def test_get_image(self): loc = Location('test_rbd_store', rbd_store.StoreLocation, self.conf, store_specs=self.store_specs) data = "" image, size = self.store.get(loc) for chunk in image: data += chunk self.assertEqual("abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz", data) def test_get_partial_image_with_default_offset(self): loc = Location('test_rbd_store', rbd_store.StoreLocation, self.conf, store_specs=self.store_specs) data = "" image, size = self.store.get(loc, chunk_size=3) for chunk in image: data += chunk self.assertEqual("abc", data) def test_get_partial_image_with_default_length(self): loc = Location('test_rbd_store', rbd_store.StoreLocation, self.conf, store_specs=self.store_specs) data = "" image, size = self.store.get(loc, offset=10) for chunk in image: data += chunk self.assertEqual("klmnopqrstuvwxyz", data) data = "" image, size = self.store.get(loc, offset=10, chunk_size=3) for chunk in image: data += chunk self.assertEqual("klm", data) def test_get_partial_image_with_length_out_of_boundaries(self): loc = Location('test_rbd_store', rbd_store.StoreLocation, self.conf, store_specs=self.store_specs) data = "" image, size = self.store.get(loc, offset=10, chunk_size=30) for chunk in image: data += chunk self.assertEqual("klmnopqrstuvwxyz", data)

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/murano refs/changes/15/271415/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ In murano, applications can belong to a category or multiple categories. Administrative users can create and delete a category as well as list available categories and view details for a particular category. Create a category ----------------- To create a category, use the following command specifying the category name: .. code-block:: console murano category-create <NAME> Delete a category ----------------- To delete a category, use the following command specifying the ID of a category or multiple categories to delete: .. code-block:: console murano category-delete <ID> [<ID> ...] .. note:: A category may be deleted only if no packages belong to this category. List available categories ------------------------- To get a list of all existing categories, run: .. code-block:: console murano category-list Show category details --------------------- To see packages that belong to a particular category, use the following command specifying the category ID: .. code-block:: console murano category-show <ID>

commit_message:
Added duplicate action buttons

There are Details information pages in each of Clusters, Cluster Templates,
Node Group Templates, Jobs, Job Templates, Job Binaries and Data Sources panels.
This patch adds duplicate action buttons to header of each of these panels.

Closes-bug: 1532780
Change-Id: Idcbf4069849cc999a9e6f66ba498de47b97ceb6a

commit_message:
GET on an action_plan provides first_action_uuid

Whenever trying to get the first action related to a given action
plan, we were getting back a 'null' value from the API even though
we knew there were actions to be linked to it in the DB.
So I fixed this issue and added a related unit test.

Change-Id: I1fa755f24fbf37ecd6ce2cc2396658fca8743a1c
Closes-Bug: #1538130

commit_message:
Correct parsing of bootstrap_admin_node.log

This commit fixes parsing of $goodline and $badline strings
in the 'bootstrap_admin_node.log' which causes incorrect
behaviour of VirtualBox scripts under Windows 10.

Change-Id: Ib90582adf4d5b3aa03ade081d788e5177add4b93
(cherry-pick from commit 275b5ce12e442a2900196b53f386b90bed9a49ab)
Closes-Bug: #1538143

commit_message:
Remove code deprecated in liberty cycle

  This commit removes all code that was related to deprecations,
  including tests put in during the liberty release cycle and
  increases the verbosity of warnings provided for code deprecated
  during this cycle (Mitaka).

Change-Id: I991654c6c0706eea31a6702703596e73080bec4e

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-01-27 01:12:19.000000000', 'files': ['futurist/__init__.py', 'futurist/_futures.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/futurist/commit/588c0770e98124bef83d9f2839ce6092989437a4', 'message': 'Expose underlying futures.CancelledError

When a future is cancelled and the result is fetched
it will raise a CancelledError which is quite useful to
be able to catch.

So to enable catching that specific exception expose it
in futurist __init__.py so that people can easily catch

Change-Id: I7bc1838aadcbb8cd0d635da83bb1e1b1ec761e89
'}]
commit_message:
Expose underlying futures.CancelledError

When a future is cancelled and the result is fetched
it will raise a CancelledError which is quite useful to
be able to catch.

So to enable catching that specific exception expose it
in futurist __init__.py so that people can easily catch
it just by catching futurist.CancelledError and handling
the outcome of that.

Change-Id: I7bc1838aadcbb8cd0d635da83bb1e1b1ec761e89
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/futurist refs/changes/58/272858/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: CancelledError = _futures.CancelledError

commit_message:
Fix torpid coordinator unit tests

The test_coordination.py unit module tests a _reconnect() method
which does a randomly seeded exponential retry backoff.  This
retry/backoff mechanism introduces needless delay in unit test
runs.

This commit mocks out random.uniform, improving run time by about
a factor of nine, as documented in the accompanying bug.

Closes-Bug: #1536750

Change-Id: I83fafba17be99cbe972dfb60fe87dac6dc3756cf

commit_message:
Correct 'hide_fields_in_newer_versions' method name

'hide_fields_in_newer_versions' actually hide fields for client
with older versions, use 'hide_fields_in_older_versions' instead.

Change-Id: I57e0c8f7fad9e53481ec59160038dc90926c0f64

subject: Cache the ARP entries in L3 Agent for DVR
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-10-23 16:14:00.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/6f8bb2bc5aad88873bfb4d775e708a3eb3768d01', 'message': 'Cache the ARP entries in L3 Agent for DVR

There seems to be a timing issue between the
ARP entries that arrive from the server to
the agent and the internal qr-device getting
created by the agent.
So those unsuccessful arp entries are dropped.

This patch makes sure that the early ARP entries
are cached in the agent and then utilized when
the internal device is up.

Closes-Bug: #1501086
Change-Id: I9ec5412f14808de73e8dd86e3d51593946d312a0
(cherry picked from commit d9fb3a66b4aead65fac2df08a5f34538e7af4d7b)
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-01-06 01:57:47.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/efa2b6325bda2ebf858c0d5b0765b0ed6268ddbf', 'message': 'Cache the ARP entries in L3 Agent for DVR

There seems to be a timing issue between the
ARP entries that arrive from the server to
the agent and the internal qr-device getting
created by the agent.
So those unsuccessful arp entries are dropped.

This patch makes sure that the early ARP entries
are cached in the agent and then utilized when
the internal device is up.

Closes-Bug: #1501086

commit_message:
Cache the ARP entries in L3 Agent for DVR

There seems to be a timing issue between the
ARP entries that arrive from the server to
the agent and the internal qr-device getting
created by the agent.
So those unsuccessful arp entries are dropped.

This patch makes sure that the early ARP entries
are cached in the agent and then utilized when
the internal device is up.

Closes-Bug: #1501086
Change-Id: I9ec5412f14808de73e8dd86e3d51593946d312a0
(cherry picked from commit d9fb3a66b4aead65fac2df08a5f34538e7af4d7b)

added_lines: with mock.patch.object(ri, '_process_arp_cache_for_internal_port') as parp: ri._set_subnet_arp_info(subnet_id) self.assertEqual(1, parp.call_count) def _setup_test_for_arp_entry_cache(self): agent = l3_agent.L3NATAgent(HOSTNAME, self.conf) router = l3_test_common.prepare_router_data(num_internal_ports=2) router['distributed'] = True ri = dvr_router.DvrLocalRouter( agent, HOSTNAME, router['id'], router, **self.ri_kwargs) subnet_id = l3_test_common.get_subnet_id( ri.router[l3_constants.INTERFACE_KEY][0]) return ri, subnet_id def test__update_arp_entry_calls_arp_cache_with_no_device(self): ri, subnet_id = self._setup_test_for_arp_entry_cache() state = True with mock.patch.object(l3_agent.ip_lib, 'IPDevice') as rtrdev,\ mock.patch.object(ri, '_cache_arp_entry') as arp_cache: rtrdev.return_value.exists.return_value = False state = ri._update_arp_entry( mock.ANY, mock.ANY, subnet_id, 'add') self.assertFalse(state) self.assertTrue(arp_cache.called) arp_cache.assert_called_once_with(mock.ANY, mock.ANY, subnet_id, 'add') self.assertFalse(rtrdev.neigh.add.called) def test__process_arp_cache_for_internal_port(self): ri, subnet_id = self._setup_test_for_arp_entry_cache() ri._cache_arp_entry('1.7.23.11', '00:11:22:33:44:55', subnet_id, 'add') self.assertEqual(1, len(ri._pending_arp_set)) with mock.patch.object(ri, '_update_arp_entry') as update_arp: update_arp.return_value = True ri._process_arp_cache_for_internal_port(subnet_id) self.assertEqual(0, len(ri._pending_arp_set)) def test__delete_arp_cache_for_internal_port(self): ri, subnet_id = self._setup_test_for_arp_entry_cache() ri._cache_arp_entry('1.7.23.11', '00:11:22:33:44:55', subnet_id, 'add') self.assertEqual(1, len(ri._pending_arp_set)) ri._delete_arp_cache_for_internal_port(subnet_id) self.assertEqual(0, len(ri._pending_arp_set))

commit_message:
Improve the help text for the cert options

The previous commit moved all the cert options to a central location.
This commit adds additional help text to those options.

Blueprint centralize-config-options

Change-Id: Ic4d15eebefced8478e36997294264eb1951fd464
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/86/268186/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: help=""" Determines the RPC topic that the cert nodes listen on. The default is 'cert', and for most deployments there is no need to ever change it. Possible values: Any string. * Services which consume this: ``nova-cert`` * Related options: None """) help=""" Specifies the maximum version for messages sent to cert services. This should be the minimum value that is supported by all of the deployed cert services. Possible values: Any string representing a version number in the format 'N.N'; for example, possible values might be '1.12' or '2.0'. * Services which consume this: ``nova-cert`` * Related options: None """)

commit_message:
Bump tooz version in requirements

We pass in blocking when using lock via contextmanager[1] now.
this functionality was only added in 1.22[2]

[1] https://github.com/openstack/gnocchi/commit/115c275a667bf60c694d02f12800de52c857593e
[2] http://docs.openstack.org/developer/tooz/history.html#id8

Change-Id: I71f1420fb63132282ff72624b19ce61bc1efac57

commit_message:
Correct parsing of bootstrap_admin_node.log

This commit fixes parsing of $goodline and $badline strings
in the 'bootstrap_admin_node.log' which causes incorrect
behaviour of VirtualBox scripts under Windows 10.

Change-Id: Ib90582adf4d5b3aa03ade081d788e5177add4b93
Closes-Bug: #1538143
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-main refs/changes/60/272560/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: send "egrep --color=none -e '${goodline}' -e '${badline}' /var/log/puppet/bootstrap_admin_node.log\r" echo "$result" | grep -v grep | egrep -q "$badline" >&2 && return 1 echo "$result" | grep -v grep | egrep -q "$goodline" >&2 && return 0
deleted_lines: send "egrep --color=none -e '$goodline' -e '$badline' /var/log/puppet/bootstrap_admin_node.log\r" echo "$result" | egrep "$badline" >&2 && return 1 echo "$result" | egrep -q "$goodline" && return 0

commit_message:
Adds volume_driver in db api

Adds volume_driver to the following:
1. api baymodel attribute
2. a new column to the baymodel db
3. objects.Note: Updates baymodel object version
4. Unit tests

Co-Authored By: Kai Qiang Wu(Kennan)<wkqwu@cn.ibm.com>
Co-Authored By: Ton Ngo<ton@us.ibm.com>
Partially-Implements: blueprint magnum-integrate-with-cinder

commit_message:
Allow restore command with name param

when we try to restore an instance, it's already deleted state,
so we need to add 'delete=True' as default to restore command,
otherwise, the search function can't find the instance
whose state is deleted with the given name

Change-Id: I81cdc46897d76333452069a691824264ad504518
Closes-Bug: 1534644
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-novaclient refs/changes/08/272508/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Move config options from nova/cert directory

This patch moves the config options in the files in the nova/cert
directory into nova/conf/cert.py. Improved help text will follow in a
dependent patch.

Blueprint centralize-config-options

Change-Id: Ib89ed26bed85238193bfaa36f0549abaa7d9426c

commit_message:
Add network_update RPC into SR-IOV agent

SR-IOV agent doesn't listen for network_update notification, but it's
desired in QOS when network updated with a new QOS policy. This patch
adds it into this agent.

Change-Id: I06a7ca411da31bccabddec9c0adca6b8e6eab7cc
Closes-Bug: #1504166

added_lines: import collectionsclass SriovNicSwitchRpcCallbacksMixin( sg_rpc.SecurityGroupAgentRpcCallbackMixin): target = oslo_messaging.Target(version='1.4') self.updated_devices.add((mac, pci_slot)) def network_update(self, context, **kwargs): network_id = kwargs['network']['id'] for port_id in self.network_ports[network_id]: if port_id not in self.deleted_ports: self.updated_devices.add(port_id) LOG.debug("network_update message processed for network " "%(network_id)s, with ports: %(ports)s", {'network_id': network_id, 'ports': self.network_ports[network_id]}) class SriovNicSwitchAgent(SriovNicSwitchRpcCallbacksMixin): super(SriovNicSwitchAgent, self).__init__() self.network_ports = collections.defaultdict(set) def _update_port_network(self, port_id, network_id): self._clean_network_ports(port_id) self.network_ports[network_id].add(port_id) def _clean_network_ports(self, port_id): for port_set in self.network_ports.values(): if port_id in port_set: port_set.remove(port_id) break #self.endpoints = [SriovNicSwitchRpcCallbacksMixin(self.context, self, # self.sg_agent)] self.endpoints = [self] [topics.NETWORK, topics.UPDATE], self._update_port_network(device_details['port_id'], device_details['network_id']) self._clean_network_ports(port_id)
deleted_lines: class SriovNicSwitchRpcCallbacks(sg_rpc.SecurityGroupAgentRpcCallbackMixin): target = oslo_messaging.Target(version='1.1') def __init__(self, context, agent, sg_agent): super(SriovNicSwitchRpcCallbacks, self).__init__() self.context = context self.agent = agent self.sg_agent = sg_agent self.agent.updated_devices.add((mac, pci_slot)) class SriovNicSwitchAgent(object): self.endpoints = [SriovNicSwitchRpcCallbacks(self.context, self, self.sg_agent)]

commit_message:
Move StorletGatewayBase under storlet_gateway module

StorletGatewayBase is a base class for all gateway classes,
so it should be placed under storlet_gateway module, not under
storlet_middleware.

commit_message:
Remove argparse from requirements

argparse was external in python 2.6 but not anymore, remove it from
requirements.

This should help with pip 8.0 that gets confused in this situation.
Installation of the external argparse is not needed.

Change-Id: Ib7e74912b36c1b5ccb514e31fac35efeff57378d

commit_message:
Hide some table buttons at Package Definitions page

Toggle active and public are now available under
'More Actions' button. This focuses users attention
on the main import/delete actions
and allows table to looks good on small screens.

Closes-Bug: #1525340
Change-Id: I3dd70d2566defb99bc3682095b4077adf0dea052

commit_message:
Revert "Don't use internap for 2-node labels"

This reverts commit bc0bf489323e103381eec4007e9a40a513531f45.

With this in place, it should be safe to use Internap for 2-node
labels again.  Further improvements to devstack-gate should handle
this for us automatically in the future.

Change-Id: Ie82be01b5bd4e9cd75b1ff7a049fde2ef22cfbb2
Depends-On: I6c8c1101771d1c5496884be7a405285472ae803a

commit_message:
Remove some jobs from gantt

The gant repos are inactive, remove some jobs from them. Even if they
are not run, changes to e.g. integrated gate template might need
changes for gantt. Remove translation jobs (gantt is not translated),
as well as integrated-gate (client is not part of it anymore, this only
confuses), grenade, large-ops.

Change-Id: I69a7bb7ebe0bf83959033810e1b3795ffe47f953
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/11/271911/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Update pingtest for newer heatclient

I assume this works in tripleoci now because we are
pinned to an old delorean repo. Using current, the
`heat output-show` command returns a table which is
not directly pingable. The '-v' flag makes it return
a value instead.

We will definitely need this patch to bump the
current-tripleo delorean hash.

Change-Id: I25e46a3d7ea10cd1748a9c602661f4d42f2b478a

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-01-25 16:04:28.000000000', 'files': ['puppet/manifests/overcloud_controller_pacemaker.pp'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/commit/403b182d94bff370d88c34d283929c133fd0a699', 'message': 'Remove empty value for wsrep_notify_cmd

This was being silently ignored by the mysql puppet module

This is not currently failing on master because we are

this is breaking stable/liberty HA job because we use the
packaged OPM there.

[1] https://github.com/puppetlabs/puppetlabs-mysql/commit/e30e0bc958761890ea4f06cdd3f1fc7242a00fe2

Change-Id: I9e07efe1650831e81e9a783428554578874aa765

commit_message:
Remove empty value for wsrep_notify_cmd

This was being silently ignored by the mysql puppet module
prior to this commit.[1] However, now that empty values are
allowed, the overcloud deploy fails because the option
--wsrep_notify_cmd requires an argument.

This is not currently failing on master because we are
pinned to an old puppet-mysql. We will need to remove that
pin in order to get on a newer delorean repo though. Also,
this is breaking stable/liberty HA job because we use the
packaged OPM there.

[1] https://github.com/puppetlabs/puppetlabs-mysql/commit/e30e0bc958761890ea4f06cdd3f1fc7242a00fe2

Change-Id: I9e07efe1650831e81e9a783428554578874aa765
Closes-Bug: 1537720

commit_message:
Tegile tests: Change volume size to int

Defining volume size as a string is not correct, and
causes huge memory consumption when multiplied by
units.Gi in the driver.

Change-Id: Ib4cf13629b70dc1c517e4c12f29c62bb9c75adbf
Closes-Bug: #1535464

commit_message:
Introduce new tests for backup-restore feature

We should check that real-world use case with complete reinstallation(or replacement)
of fuel master node do not break the feature and fuel.
Aslo this patch introduces new method that allow to reinstall fuel master node from scratch

Change-Id: Ifa4305e3ff6277f832c0e3701d511dee89eeae47
Closes-bug:#1535119
(cherry picked from commit 7192d8690e82d985529d3c0716ff2704732f83e3)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-qa refs/changes/70/272970/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import osfrom fuelweb_test import settings @test(groups=["backup_reinstall_restore"]) class BackupReinstallRestoreHA(NeutronTunHaBase): """This test dedicated for verifying dockerctl backup/restore feature with complete re-installation of Fuel after backing up""" @test(depends_on_groups=['deploy_neutron_tun_ha_backup_restore'], groups=["backup_reinstall_restore"]) @log_snapshot_after_test def backup_reinstall_restore(self): """Backup, reinstall then restore master node with cluster in ha mode Scenario: 1. Revert snapshot "deploy_neutron_tun_ha" 2. Backup master 3. Check backup 4. Reinstall fuel-master node 5. Restore master 6. Check restore 7. Run OSTF 8. Add 1 compute 9. Run network check 10. Deploy cluster 11. Run OSTF Duration XXm """ self.env.revert_snapshot("deploy_neutron_tun_ha_backup_restore") cluster_id = self.fuel_web.get_last_created_cluster() with self.env.d_env.get_admin_remote() as remote: self.fuel_web.backup_master(remote) checkers.backup_check(remote) backup = checkers.find_backup(remote).strip() local_backup = os.path.join( settings.LOGS_DIR, os.path.basename(backup)) remote.download(backup, local_backup) assert_true(os.path.exists(local_backup), "Backup file wasn't downloaded!") self.env.reinstall_master_node() with self.env.d_env.get_admin_remote() as remote: remote.execute('mkdir -p {}'.format(os.path.dirname(backup))) remote.upload(local_backup, backup) assert_true(remote.exists(backup), "Backup file wasn't uploaded!") with RunLimit( seconds=60 * 10, error_message="'dockerctl restore' " "run longer then 600 sec"): self.fuel_web.restore_master(remote) checkers.restore_check_sum(remote) self.fuel_web.restore_check_nailgun_api() checkers.iptables_check(remote) assert_equal( 5, len(self.fuel_web.client.list_cluster_nodes(cluster_id))) self.env.bootstrap_nodes(self.env.d_env.nodes().slaves[5:6], skip_timesync=True) self.fuel_web.update_nodes(cluster_id, {'slave-06': ['compute']}) self.fuel_web.verify_network(cluster_id) self.fuel_web.deploy_cluster_wait(cluster_id) self.fuel_web.run_ostf( cluster_id=cluster_id, test_sets=['ha', 'smoke', 'sanity']) self.env.make_snapshot("neutron_tun_ha_backup_restore")

commit_message:
Introduce new tests for backup-restore feature

We should check that real-world use case with complete reinstallation(or replacement)
of fuel master node do not break the feature and fuel.
Aslo this patch introduces new method that allow to reinstall fuel master node from scratch

Change-Id: Ifa4305e3ff6277f832c0e3701d511dee89eeae47
Closes-bug:#1535119

commit_message:
Change Swift zero-size chunk behaviour

There is a difference in how Swift and radosgw behave when a zero
length write is aborted. Swift returns 499 and doesn't create an object,
but radosgw appears to creates a zero size object. Because of this, new
behaviour which was introduced to prevent zero-size chunks being written
worked for Swift, but appears not to work for the radosgw case.

This patch changes how we detect a zero size chunk so that no request
is made to the backend. We no longer rely on the Swift specific behaviour.

Change-Id: I1a48e2eceaa6b07b8e5bbfd42fef6fd3d91f5834
Closes-bug: 1537721

commit_message:
Rename django-openstack-auth to django_openstack_auth

This is the proper pypi name which makes lookup easier. Also it matches
the name listed in the global requirements and makes setup possible
in stricter environmenets.

Change-Id: I79fed060260c28fbe5a8578cfd58609a672681a6

commit_message:
Open specs for Newton

Now we have the name for newton, we should open specs so people can
start targeting changes, either new or deferrals from Mitaka.

commit_message:
Run the ofagent ci job on the periodic-neutron queue

As the ofagnet depends on the neutron, the ofagent is affected by a change
for the neutron and some changes may break the ofagent.
So we want to run periodically ofagent job with the latest neutron repo
to verify that the ofagent isn't broken them.

As the ofagent ci job is stable, we put it to the periodic-neutron queue.

Change-Id: I0c6d371edd77e42c9cde6bf79bbd07164733e50f

commit_message:
Make no response notification(msg) level to INFO

Some API calls just sent but the results were uncertain,
Horizon should notify the user that your request is
just accepted, not successfully.
So this patch change some form message level to INFO,
and some message expression.

Change-Id: I90c6b5aeb8b93adfd6bbd1e996cdeb8514f644a2
Co-Authored-By: LIU Yulong <yulong@cloudcraft.cn>
Closes-Bug: #1326301
Closes-Bug: #1286418

added_lines: messages.info(request, _("Stack creation started.")) messages.info(request, _("Stack update started."))
deleted_lines: messages.success(request, _("Stack creation started.")) messages.success(request, _("Stack update started."))

commit_message:
Run ovs-native jobs on the periodic-neutron queue

ovs driver with native of_interface isn't tested on tempest job
by default. We want to run periodically ovs-native jobs to verify
that the ovs driver with native of_interface works well with
the latest neutron codes.

Currently ovs-native jobs are run on the experimental queue and
it seems to be stable. So we can run them on the periodic-neutron
queue.

Change-Id: I60df32e200200b42a3b54167538dc9315592fa52

subject: Fix default mutables for set_acls
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-01-21 10:02:45.000000000', 'files': ['glance_store/driver.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/glance_store/commit/caed3b169f1db94ba58d6e702e1ee90fcee7c6b4', 'message': 'Fix default mutables for set_acls

read_tenants, write_tenants parameters in set_acls method of
glance_store/driver.Store have empty lists as default values.
It is not recommended approach cause it can lead to some neat
issues.

Moreover, Swift store class rewrites this method and uses None as
default values (which is right). So we need to follow this
approach in base Store class.

Change-Id: Ifa0f0c286dbb822b2d34d03978655d720bb109d4
'}]
commit_message:
Fix default mutables for set_acls

read_tenants, write_tenants parameters in set_acls method of
glance_store/driver.Store have empty lists as default values.
It is not recommended approach cause it can lead to some neat
issues.

Moreover, Swift store class rewrites this method and uses None as
default values (which is right). So we need to follow this
approach in base Store class.

Change-Id: Ifa0f0c286dbb822b2d34d03978655d720bb109d4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance_store refs/changes/01/270701/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def set_acls(self, location, public=False, read_tenants=None, write_tenants=None, context=None):
deleted_lines: def set_acls(self, location, public=False, read_tenants=[], write_tenants=[], context=None):

commit_message:
Pass the proper params to getPorts call

Fixes the proper params to pass for the neutron ports
call by accepting a dictionary with param_name:value
as this is whats expected from neutron client/API

Change-Id: I75d63f561cac97d2f8e0370f39f260a40029d685
Closes-Bug: #1536586
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/49/270749/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: * @param {string} params.other * Any additional request parameters will be passed through the API as * filters. For example "status" : "ACTIVE" would filter on the status. function getPorts(params) { var config = (params) ? { 'params' : params} : {}; return apiService.get('/api/neutron/ports/', config)
deleted_lines: * @param {string} networkId * The network id to retrieve ports for. Required. function getPorts(networkId) { return apiService.get('/api/neutron/ports/', networkId)

commit_message:
Dismiss glance-drivers team

The Glance Drivers team is being dismissed in favor of a single glance
core team. This patch gives the core team rights on glance-specs.

Change-Id: I6a2b18e51d319ed12c35c93e182215767e158434

commit_message:
Revert "Remove unnecessary auth module"

This reverts commit 3331ac6b4c86a73a060cf9a613537d364ac4bbb3.

During the testing of glance_store master it turns out that
we are not passing request context as object to glance_store.
it is list value now.
So we need to revert the patch that uses url_for and
propose more reliable solution.

Conflicts:
	glance_store/_drivers/swift/store.py
	glance_store/tests/unit/test_swift_store.py

Change-Id: I66ea733fd3fdccf20d525ac4460564350e5bfb32

commit_message:
Remove argparse from requirements

argparse was external in python 2.6 but not anymore, remove it from
requirements.

This should help with pip 8.0 that gets confused in this situation.
Installation of the external argparse is not needed.

Change-Id: Ib7e74912b36c1b5ccb514e31fac35efeff57378d

commit_message:
Do not pass both port-id and fixed-ip to create server

Nova doesn't allow specify port-id and fixed-ip at the same
time when create server. This patch to avoid this problem
when create internal port by subnet.

Also, this change adds integration test for create server
with subnet and fixed_ip.

Change-Id: Ib16d7f90a4eb488a853f9c2093280596fc4d783b
Partial-Bug: #1533074

Fix indents of servers-detail-resp.json

indents which are made with tabs instead of spaces.

subject: Process git repos in role defaults at low priority
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-01-19 04:39:46.000000000', 'files': ['playbooks/plugins/lookups/py_pkgs.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible/commit/286b0e5b1ff324198c772fe91f5930208552d8d9', 'message': "Process git repos in role defaults at low priority

Instead of never processing a git repository defined in a role's
defaults, include it only if that repository is not defined somewhere
else (repo_packages). This allows for independent roles to define git
repositories without necessarily being included in this central

Change-Id: If303a4cd6fab9129b54879df9aed3fc8e88295ed
"}]
commit_message:
Process git repos in role defaults at low priority

Instead of never processing a git repository defined in a role's
defaults, include it only if that repository is not defined somewhere
else (repo_packages). This allows for independent roles to define git
repositories without necessarily being included in this central
repository, or for the possibility of git repo definitions moving more
exclusively to tagged independent roles.

Change-Id: If303a4cd6fab9129b54879df9aed3fc8e88295ed
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/29/269429/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _process_git(self, loaded_yaml, git_item, yaml_file_name): # This conditional is set to ensure we're only processing git # repos from the defaults file when those same repos are not # being set in the repo_packages files. if '/defaults/main' in yaml_file_name: if name in GIT_PACKAGE_DEFAULT_PARTS: return if key.endswith('git_repo'): self._process_git( loaded_yaml=loaded_config, git_item=key, yaml_file_name=file_name )
deleted_lines: def _process_git(self, loaded_yaml, git_item): # This conditional is set to ensure we're not processes git # repos from the defaults file which may conflict with what is # being set in the repo_packages files. if '/defaults/main' not in file_name: if key.endswith('git_repo'): self._process_git( loaded_yaml=loaded_config, git_item=key )

commit_message:
Add address scope to floating IPs in RPC response to L3 agent

The L3 agent needs to know the address scope of the fixed ip of each
floating ip because floating ips are a way to cross scope boundaries.
Without the scope information, there could be ambiguity and no way to
know which scope to send it to.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/189741/

Conflicts:
        doc/source/devref/address_scopes.rst
        neutron/tests/unit/db/test_l3_db.py

Change-Id: Id9f8c12954a6efbf4d9b99c011652eefbe5f5145
Partially-Implements: blueprint address-scopes
(cherry picked from commit 02439b6730444d29f139dcc12536f0d2d02a51f7)

added_lines: # Copyright 2015 Hewlett-Packard Development Company, L.P. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); # you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. # You may obtain a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, # WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or # implied. # See the License for the specific language governing permissions and # limitations under the License. import mock from neutron.db import l3_db from neutron.tests import base class TestL3_NAT_dbonly_mixin(base.BaseTestCase): def setUp(self): super(TestL3_NAT_dbonly_mixin, self).setUp() self.db = l3_db.L3_NAT_dbonly_mixin() def test__get_sync_floating_ips_no_query(self): """Basic test that no query is performed if no router ids are passed""" db = l3_db.L3_NAT_dbonly_mixin() context = mock.Mock() db._get_sync_floating_ips(context, []) self.assertFalse(context.session.query.called) @mock.patch.object(l3_db.L3_NAT_dbonly_mixin, '_make_floatingip_dict') def test__make_floatingip_dict_with_scope(self, make_fip_dict): db = l3_db.L3_NAT_dbonly_mixin() make_fip_dict.return_value = {'id': mock.sentinel.fip_ip} result = db._make_floatingip_dict_with_scope( mock.sentinel.floating_ip_db, mock.sentinel.address_scope_id) self.assertEqual({ 'fixed_ip_address_scope': mock.sentinel.address_scope_id, 'id': mock.sentinel.fip_ip}, result) def test__unique_floatingip_iterator(self): query = mock.MagicMock() query.order_by().__iter__.return_value = [ ({'id': 'id1'}, 'scope1'), ({'id': 'id1'}, 'scope1'), ({'id': 'id2'}, 'scope2'), ({'id': 'id2'}, 'scope2'), ({'id': 'id2'}, 'scope2'), ({'id': 'id3'}, 'scope3')] query.reset_mock() result = list( l3_db.L3_NAT_dbonly_mixin._unique_floatingip_iterator(query)) query.order_by.assert_called_once_with(l3_db.FloatingIP.id) self.assertEqual([({'id': 'id1'}, 'scope1'), ({'id': 'id2'}, 'scope2'), ({'id': 'id3'}, 'scope3')], result)

commit_message:
Add the keyfile option to decrypt the passwords.yml

The passed keyfile path is used to decrypt the passwords.yml
which encrypted by the ansible vault.

Partially-Implements: blueprint	encrypt-sensitive-info
DocImpact
Change-Id: Ifaebf464478cde99e896c13b375cfaf9282ee576
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/84/271184/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: function encrypt_pass_file { [[ -f $VAULT_PASS_FILE ]] || { echo "Please create the password file $VAULT_PASS_FILE with your encrypt"\ "password in and make sure it is not readable by others!" exit 1 } ansible-vault encrypt --vault-password-file=$VAULT_PASS_FILE /etc/kolla/passwords.yml } VAULT_PASS_FILE=~/.vault_pass.txtEXTRA_OPTS="$EXTRA_OPTS --vault-password-file=$VAULT_PASS_FILE"encrypt_pass_file

commit_message:
Add translation jobs to murano-dashboard

Murano-dashboard is a dashboard for horizon, therefore shares the same
message structure as horizon does, i.e. django and djangojs .pot files.

The scripts are all in place, we now need to only add the job to zuul.

Targets blueprint: murano-i18n

Change-Id: Id7c7d6e5da310be5a03b60b230bd607f2f9f476a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/73/262073/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Setup project murano-dashboard for Zanata function setup_murano_dashboard { local project=murano-dashboard local version=${1:-master} /usr/local/jenkins/slave_scripts/create-zanata-xml.py \ -p $project -v $version --srcdir muranodashboard/locale \ --txdir muranodashboard/locale -r '**/*.pot' \ '{locale_with_underscore}/LC_MESSAGES/{filename}.po' -f zanata.xml }

commit_message:
Update ring builder filenames in Swift config

Update Swift config playbook to use correct name of Swift ring
builer file. Those are the names generated if one follows document in
doc/swift-guide.rst

TrivialFix

Change-Id: If1d713e3cccc851ef6f2cc3cb5a736b43fa26957

commit_message:
Switch to oslo.cache lib

Common memorycache was replaced by analogous tool
from oslo.cache lib. In-memory cache was replaced
by oslo.cache.dict backend. Memcached was replaced
by dogpile.cache.memcached backend.

DocImpact: 'memcached_servers' opt is deprecated in Mitaka,
in N release oslo.cache config options will control this.
The deprecated option will be replaced by 'cache.memcache_servers'
option.

Closes-Bug: #1483322
Co-Authored-By: Sergey Nikitin <snikitin@mirantis.com>

Change-Id: Ia120bcc2f057c9991389092fdbd181fdd60c7813

added_lines: from oslo_cache import core as cachecache.configure(CONF) CONF.set_override('backend', 'oslo_cache.dict', group='cache') def get_oslo_cache_client(backend=None, expiration_time=None): if not backend: backend = CONF.cache.backend if not expiration_time: expiration_time = CONF.cache.expiration_time region = cache.create_region() region.configure(backend, arguments={'expiration_time': expiration_time}) return region

commit_message:
skip most tests on a locale import

The locale files are only tested by the pep8 target, nothing else in
all of openstack tests these are working. We shouldn't run
devstack or unit test jobs on these changes.

This is added for neutron, ironic, horizon, heat.

Change-Id: I7966ff660dfc749a4176cc8d5067598e368cbc34

commit_message:
Add method for update plugin settings

Plugin API was changed. If we have several installed versions of same
plugin, it's necessary to take into account his id to configure settings.

Change-Id: Ie8da43addfc36901af73d232b191cd6a77a523bc
Closes-bug: #1533085
(cherry picked from commit 692bc08bb94390611c07d540fd77c8856500e9f8)

Check plugin version. Test aborted" assert_true( self.fuel_web.check_plugin_exists( self.cluster_id, self.plugin_name), msg) plugin_data = self.fuel_web.get_plugin_data(self.cluster_id, self.plugin_name, self.plugin_version) options = {'metadata/enabled': True, 'metadata/chosen_id': plugin_data['metadata']['plugin_id']} self.fuel_web.update_plugin_data(self.cluster_id, self.plugin_name, options) options = {'vmware_dvs_net_maps/value': self.full_config[ self.fuel_web.update_plugin_settings( self.cluster_id, self.plugin_name, self.plugin_version, options) plugin_version = DVS_PLUGIN_VERSION plugin_version = DVS_PLUGIN_VERSION

subject: Reduce keystone cache expiration time
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-01-27 09:49:35.000000000', 'files': ['playbooks/roles/os_keystone/templates/keystone.conf.j2', 'playbooks/roles/os_keystone/defaults/main.yml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible/commit/50756bdff1793e3a239a60f745ac6197a51e9788', 'message': 'Reduce keystone cache expiration time

This commit removes the keystone_cache_expiration_time variable,
allowing deployers to override using standard config overrides.

Additionally, we /temporarily/ disable catalog caching in
keystone.conf.j2 to unblock our master gate.

Note that this change is necessary as we have been experiencing
fairly consistent gate failures in master where the tempest role is
unable to upload an image to glance.  This causes the tempest run to
fail since the expected image is not available.  This upstream keystone
review [1] introduced a change to add catalog caching, and what we are
actually seeing is glance failing to upload the image (or create the
necessary directory in swift) as the object-store endpoint is not in
the catalog which it gets back from keystone.  When this happens we are
presumably hitting a stale cache entry which will not expire for 5400
seconds (the old value of keystone_cache_expiration_time).

For some additional information (as provided by dolphm), it looks like
endpoint updates invalidate portions of the dogpile cache but not all.
There is a fix in flight [2] to address this.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/215212/
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/271536/

UpgradeImpact
Related-bug: #1537617

Change-Id: I3b2a833a3e96a3b5deac76052eed480ddcb6175d
(cherry picked from commit c0fa60b3d66ea60cd8a611d72c54fddf5b0e94eb)
'}]
commit_message:
Reduce keystone cache expiration time

This commit removes the keystone_cache_expiration_time variable,
allowing deployers to override using standard config overrides.

Additionally, we /temporarily/ disable catalog caching in
keystone.conf.j2 to unblock our master gate.

Note that this change is necessary as we have been experiencing
fairly consistent gate failures in master where the tempest role is
unable to upload an image to glance.  This causes the tempest run to
fail since the expected image is not available.  This upstream keystone
review [1] introduced a change to add catalog caching, and what we are
actually seeing is glance failing to upload the image (or create the
necessary directory in swift) as the object-store endpoint is not in
the catalog which it gets back from keystone.  When this happens we are
presumably hitting a stale cache entry which will not expire for 5400
seconds (the old value of keystone_cache_expiration_time).

For some additional information (as provided by dolphm), it looks like
endpoint updates invalidate portions of the dogpile cache but not all.
There is a fix in flight [2] to address this.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/215212/
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/271536/

UpgradeImpact
Related-bug: #1537617

Change-Id: I3b2a833a3e96a3b5deac76052eed480ddcb6175d
(cherry picked from commit c0fa60b3d66ea60cd8a611d72c54fddf5b0e94eb)

commit_message:
Locking servers by service token

A way for heat to create servers inside a users tenant,
but the tenant is not able to delete those servers.

blueprint protected-resources

Change-Id: Id501ab06ee7c6052e4c824644ed65468ddf15dd9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/80/203880/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================================ Protected resources in OpenStack ================================ https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/protected-resources OpenStack projects like Nova, Cinder, Trove, Sahara, Cue and Murano, Heat need a way to protect resources they have created with other OpenStack projects, so they can deliver more reliable and friendly services to cloud users. Problem description =================== OpenStack projects interact with and create resources with other OpenStack projects, in order to deliver their services and fulfil their mission. For example: * Nova and Cinder store backups in Swift (using Glance) and would like to prevent users from deleting these backup objects directly; * Trove, Sahara, Cue, Murano and Heat launch instances, volumes and other resources using Nova, Cinder, Neutron, etc, and would like to prevent users from interacting directly with them. To make it easier to describe what this blueprint is aiming to achieve, we will use the Heat project as an example. That being said, please keep in mind that this is a general issue and could be equally illustrated using other projects. When Heat deploys a compute instance on behalf of a user, it currently has got no way to prevent this compute instances from being manipulated directly by users via nova. As a result, a user could [delete, resize, shut down, etc.] a compute instance, making a heat stack unhealthy (if not completely broken). From Heat's point of view, it is currently impossible to prevent this from happening. A user can easily delete an instance that belongs to Heat and be surprised later with his broken stack (without correlating these two events, therefore violating the principle of least surprise). Moreover, it is very hard for Heat to provide reasonable error messages or behave in a user friendly way, when the resources it expects to find in a given state are now in a different state, or not even there any more. Use Cases ---------- When an OpenStack project creates a resource with another project (for example: Nova creates a backup object in Swift via Glance, Heat creates an instance with Nova), they should be able to tag these resources as belonging to them. Other projects should respect these tags and prompt users to use the original service that tagged them to interact with these resources. This will allow projects to deliver more consistent behaviour to users (less surprises) and have better error handling and error messages (eg: Could not delete instance, because it is being used by a Heat Stack. Please use the Heat service to manipulate this compute instance). Project Priority ----------------- As a community, we have reached the tipping point where the pain caused by this is unbearable. The number of projects requiring this capability grows every day. We need to provide a method for these projects to achieve their goals with a common, well understood and supported design pattern that can be implemented by all projects. This topic has been discussed extensively at the Vancouver summit and its need was backed by the PTLs of the following projects: Trove, Sahara, Cue, Heat. A brief discussion with the Nova team also highlighted their own desire to have this ability with other projects. Proposed change =============== Initially, we would like to see Nova providing a mechanism for Heat to protect compute instances launched by it. In this blueprint we do not specify how this should be done, but rather invite the Nova team to identify the options and define the best way to move forward. We acknowledge there are multiple ways this could be achieved and trust the Nova team is ultimately in the best position to suggest the best and easiest way to move forward. Alternatives ------------ Besides tagging resources, Glance and Swift have a new system that require tokens for two tenants to access a resource. Nova could mimic this behaviour to achieve this. It would be good if the method utilised allowed projects to easily identify the original project that created the resource, so that reasonable error messages (or warnings) can be presented to users trying to manipulate them directly. We have discussed the idea of hiding a protected compute instance (or resource) from users. This idea has been quickly shut down due to its indirect implications, such as: * Quota usage not being transparent to cloud users (a hidden instance is using their quota and users do not understand why they cannot launch another instance) * Not exposing useful information to cloud users, such as the network that their protected compute instances are connected to on the network topology view. We are open to other suggestions, but for now have a preference to display the protected resources and disable operations to be performed on them. As a result, particularly from the dashboard (Horizon) point of view, we will potentially need to mark or highlight these resources in a different way. We have also discussed the idea of launching these protected resources into a separate tenant, owned by the cloud operator. While this may make some sense for projects like Trove, deploying their services into compute instances, it makes no sense at all for projects like Heat. Moreover, we have concerns that: a) The isolation level provided by multiple instances on the same tenant that belong to multiple customers is not as strong as tenancy isolation in OpenStack. As a community we have invested a great deal of effort making sure tenancy isolation is strong across all projects (and we did a great job). On the other hand, we believe there are implicit assumptions all over the place that resources belonging to the same tenant should be accessible to the owner of this tenant. If a single instance is compromised, there is more opportunity for lateral movement and compromise of resources that effectively belong to other tenants. b) Piping the network connectivity from the customer tenant to the cloud owner tenant is not straightforward or as flexible as having the resource on the customer tenant. Impact ------ We are open to other suggestions, but for now have a preference to display the protected resources and disable operations to be performed on them. As a result, particularly from the dashboard (Horizon) point of view, we will potentially need to mark or highlight these resources in a different way. The APIs may need a new error response that indicates to cloud users that a given operation is not allowed directly and prompts them to use the service that created these resources to interact with them. Depending on how we implement this, we may be capable of even mentioning the name of the project they should use on the error message. API documentation may need to be updated with new error codes or responses. User documentation will need to be updated explaining why certain resources cannot be manipulated directly.

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/28/178628/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. Copyright 2010-2011 United States Government as represented by the Administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. All Rights Reserved. Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain a copy of the License at http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations under the License. Flavors and Image Properties ============================= Flavor tells users the slot they are buying with their boot request. The image describes the root disk contents and the requirements to make that image boot, such as min size of the root disk, etc. Overtime there are now lots of extra-specs added to flavors, image properties and host aggregate groups that affect either what features the VM gets, where the VM is placed, if the VM can boot with the given flavor or on a given host. Why flavors are useful ----------------------- Firstly flavors are a great way to bill or charge-back for the resources people use in your cloud. Capacity planning can be hard. Flavors help reduce the complexity for that process. You can size your infrastructure to match the flavors you offer, to minimise unusable capacity. Its common to group flavors and match each group to different types of hosts to offer different ratios of resources, but still keeping the capacity planning relatively simple. A commonly requested feature is to have quotas based on number of instances of each flavor type, rather than quotas based purely on RAM or disk. While we have not yet followed through on that, it is an attractive way to deal with quotas. Problems -------- We really need to formalise more of this work. Sometimes users must create a snapshot purely to specify an image property for a new instance, this is very wrong. Many users feel restricted by the list of available flavors. Some deployments have a dizzying array of flavors with different properties, and would benefit from grouping them into "classes" of flavors. Networking Customization ------------------------- When booting an instance people can add arbitrary neutron ports to their VMs. This is all outside the Nova quota system, and Neutron has to deal with any restrictions and billing of resources. It's hard to give a good user experience with this split without users creating their ports in neutron before booting their instance. This can lead to discussions about if those ports should be destroyed when the instance is destroyed. Despite its problems this is quite a clean split of responsibilities. Disks and Block device mapping ------------------------------- The flavor concept assumes a disk managed locally on the hypervisor. Cinder now controls all remotely managed disks. Now cinder supports local volumes and Nova supports having instance disks stored on storage shared between various hypervisors. When booting, and hotpugging after booting, you can add additional storage to your VM by passing in a cinder volume to attach. When you "boot from volume" you replace the root disk defined in your flavor with the specified Cinder volume. It's also possible you specify an image to create a volume from, where the size of that volume is taken from the size of your root disk in the flavor. When booting, if you flavor includes ephemeral disks, you can use block device mapping API to change how you split up the storage into multiple disks. These are all nova managed disks. By convention a snapshot includes only the root disk and not any ephemeral disks. When you have volumes attached, they are sometimes snapshotted TODO - find out details!! There is a special case of a 0 gb root disk. This was added for testing. It means the root disk is unrestricted in size, more precisely keeps its original size in the image you choose. It does not restrict the user to having a cinder based root disk, as you might assume. When considering how you bill for these, it gets confusing. Volumes are billed as a cinder resource, nova resources are generally billed using the flavor. Consider boot from volume for a flavor with a big root disk, you get billed for the large unused base disk, unless you create specific flavors for boot from volume. Extending Flavors ------------------ Initially Nova was only creating simple VMs with a default configuration. Now we have PCI devices, CPU feature sets and various other resources that people want to give users a particular flavor. For this we used extra specs as a loose way of extending the concept of a flavor. This has recently ballooned with lots of NFV related features. It has diluted the API and is really not very discoverable. Using flavors to say when an instance gets a resource means you can use flavors to charge for these extra devices or differences in hardware. Image properties ----------------- Several options relating to extra-specs only work when the image has support for those features. For example PCI pass through only makes sense if that image has support for that hardware and the correct driver installed. In some cases you can pick a different host that does work with that image. Sometimes an image property means the build is failed unless the requirements for the flavor are met, sometimes the server just has incompatible options dropped. A big issue is when you create a new server that wants an optional feature that is only configured via an image property. Ideally you could override the image property on the boot command, but for many image properties this makes little sense. As such, we need a more formal model for these different patterns. Common patterns and anti-patterns for optional features -------------------------------------------------------- Let's identify the key patterns in existing uses of image properties, extra specs, scheduler and host aggregates currently use. * Picking the correct host * restricting builds that would always fail * adding extra resources to a server TODO - add more details Performance characteristics ---------------------------- It's worth noting the difference between booting from a glance image, booting from a volume and creating a volume to boot from. If you use a backend like RBD it's possible you don't really notice the difference, but with most other combinations quite different things are happening.

review [1] introduced a change to add catalog caching, and what we are
actually seeing is glance failing to upload the image (or create the
necessary directory in swift) as the object-store endpoint is not in
the catalog which it gets back from keystone.  When this happens we are
presumably hitting a stale cache entry which will not expire for 5400
seconds (the old value of keystone_cache_expiration_time).  By setting
the value of expiration_time to 300 seconds we should hopefully be far
less likely to get a stale cache entry back when we request the
catalog.

For some additional information (as provided by dolphm), it looks like
endpoint updates invalidate portions of the dogpile cache but not all.
It's unclear at this point in time if there will be an upstream fix for
this or if the recommended solution is to simply keep the
expiration_time low.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/215212/

UpgradeImpact

Change-Id: I3b2a833a3e96a3b5deac76052eed480ddcb6175d

commit_message:
Reduce keystone cache expiration time

This commit removes the keystone_cache_expiration_time variable,
allowing deployers to override using standard config overrides.

Additionally, we /temporarily/ disable catalog caching in
keystone.conf.j2 to unblock our master gate.

Note that this change is necessary as we have been experiencing
fairly consistent gate failures in master where the tempest role is
unable to upload an image to glance.  This causes the tempest run to
fail since the expected image is not available.  This upstream keystone
review [1] introduced a change to add catalog caching, and what we are
actually seeing is glance failing to upload the image (or create the
necessary directory in swift) as the object-store endpoint is not in
the catalog which it gets back from keystone.  When this happens we are
presumably hitting a stale cache entry which will not expire for 5400
seconds (the old value of keystone_cache_expiration_time).

For some additional information (as provided by dolphm), it looks like
endpoint updates invalidate portions of the dogpile cache but not all.
There is a fix in flight [2] to address this.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/215212/
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/271536/

UpgradeImpact
Related-bug: #1537617

Change-Id: I3b2a833a3e96a3b5deac76052eed480ddcb6175d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/57/271357/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Use ceph.conf to set default pool replica size

Use ceph.conf to set the default pool replica size, thus
avoiding the need to set replica size for each pool
separately.

Change-Id: Ib00c1666895af2332a3689ee59b9929af81a17e9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack-plugin-ceph refs/changes/70/269770/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: osd pool default size = ${CEPH_REPLICAS}
deleted_lines: # pools data and metadata were removed in the Giant release # so depending on the version we apply different commands local ceph_version ceph_version=$(get_ceph_version mon) # change pool replica size according to the CEPH_REPLICAS set by the user if [[ ${ceph_version%%.*} -eq 0 ]] && [[ ${ceph_version##*.} -lt 87 ]]; then sudo ceph -c ${CEPH_CONF_FILE} osd pool set rbd size ${CEPH_REPLICAS} sudo ceph -c ${CEPH_CONF_FILE} osd pool set data size ${CEPH_REPLICAS} sudo ceph -c ${CEPH_CONF_FILE} osd pool set metadata size ${CEPH_REPLICAS} else sudo ceph -c ${CEPH_CONF_FILE} osd pool set rbd size ${CEPH_REPLICAS} fi sudo ceph -c ${CEPH_CONF_FILE} osd pool \ set ${GLANCE_CEPH_POOL} size ${CEPH_REPLICAS} sudo ceph -c ${CEPH_CONF_FILE} osd pool set ${CEPHFS_DATA_POOL} size \ ${CEPH_REPLICAS} sudo ceph -c ${CEPH_CONF_FILE} osd pool set ${CEPHFS_METADATA_POOL} size \ ${CEPH_REPLICAS}sudo ceph -c ${CEPH_CONF_FILE} osd pool \ set ${NOVA_CEPH_POOL} size ${CEPH_REPLICAS}sudo ceph -c ${CEPH_CONF_FILE} osd pool \ set ${CINDER_CEPH_POOL} size ${CEPH_REPLICAS}
